    <script type="text/html" id="inline-audio-template">
        <!--

        // IN CASE OF ISSUES CONSIDER THIS: http://www.jplayer.org/
        // ALSO CHECK THIS FOR OTHER SOLUTIONS: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/Apps/Build/Audio_and_video_delivery/Cross-browser_audio_basics

        Inline audio player:
        - url: audio url
        - mimeType: audio mime type
        - playerClass: addirional class appended to the player container (it will be class="inline-audio playerClass")
        !-->

        <div class="inline-audio">
            <!-- ko ifnot: MManual.inlineaudio.isMovAvailable -->
            <div id="main_old_audio" data-bind="click: MManual.inlineaudio.playPause">
                <a href="#" class="inline-audio-play" data-bind="attr: { 'class': 'inline-audio-play' + (playerClass ? (' ' + playerClass) : '') }">
                    <i class="fa fa-volume-up"></i>
                </a>
                <bgsound id="sound">
            </div>
            <!-- /ko -->
            <!-- ko if: MManual.inlineaudio.isMovAvailable -->
            <div id="audio">
                <audio class="main_audio" preload="auto" onended="MManual.inlineaudio.ended(this)">
                    <!-- check if audio under topic page then add the language to the URL  !-->
                        <source data-bind="attr: {  src: url + '?la= '|| 'audio_notfound' , type: ($.isFunction(mimeType) ? mimeType() : mimeType) || 'audio/mp3' }" />
                </audio>
                <a href="#" class="inline-audio-play" data-bind="click: MManual.inlineaudio.playPause, attr: { 'class': 'inline-audio-play' + (playerClass ? (' ' + playerClass) : '') }">
                    <i class="fa fa-volume-up"></i>
                </a>
            </div>
            <!-- /ko -->
        </div>
    </script>

    <script type="text/html" id="sideline-audio-template">
        <div class="inline-audio">
            <div class="para">
                <div class="description">

<area shape=RECT coords=125,328,234,372 href=https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.msd.professional&referrer=utm_source%3DMMWeb%26utm_medium%3Dbanner%26utm_content%3DTopic1Vertical%26utm_campaign%3DWebAppAds target="_blank" alt="Android" /></map>

</div>
    </div>

        </div>
        <section class="body headers topic-content">
                <a id="v927487" class="anchor"></a>
<div class="para" >

    <p >(See also <a href="/professional/critical-care-medicine/respiratory-failure-and-mechanical-ventilation/overview-of-respiratory-failure">Respiratory Failure</a> , <a href="/professional/pulmonary-disorders/symptoms-of-pulmonary-disorders/dyspnea">Dyspnea</a>, and <a href="/professional/critical-care-medicine/respiratory-failure-and-mechanical-ventilation/acute-hypoxemic-respiratory-failure-ahrf,-ards">Hypoxia</a>.)</p>
</div>

<a id="v28604800" class="anchor"></a>
<div class="para" >

    <p >Respiratory arrest and <a href="/professional/critical-care-medicine/cardiac-arrest-and-cpr/cardiac-arrest">cardiac arrest</a> are distinct, but inevitably if untreated, one leads to the other.</p>
</div>

<a id="v927491" class="anchor"></a>
<div class="para" >

    <p >Interruption of pulmonary gas exchange for <span class ="symbol"  >></span> 5 min may irreversibly damage vital organs, especially the brain. Cardiac arrest almost always follows unless respiratory function is rapidly restored. However, aggressive ventilation may also have negative hemodynamic consequences, particularly in the periarrest period and in other circumstances when cardiac output is low. In most cases, the ultimate goal is to restore adequate ventilation and oxygenation without further compromising a tentative cardiovascular situation.</p>
</div>

<div class="headers topic-content">

        <section id="v927492" class="header  FHead" itemprop="cause" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/MedicalCause">
            <header>
                <h2 id="" ><a id="v927493"></a>Etiology</h2>
    
            </header>
            <div class="header-body">
                <a id="v927494" class="anchor"></a>
<div class="para" >

    <p >Respiratory arrest (and impaired respiration that can progress to respiratory arrest) can be caused by</p>
</div>

<div class="list">

    <ul data-mmanualobjecttype="List"  >
            <li><a id="v927497" class="anchor"></a>
<div class="para" >

    <p >Airway obstruction</p>
</div>
</li>
            <li><a id="v927499" class="anchor"></a>
<div class="para" >

    <p >Decreased respiratory effort</p>
</div>
</li>
            <li><a id="v927501" class="anchor"></a>
<div class="para" >

    <p >Respiratory muscle weakness</p>
</div>
</li>
    </ul>
</div>


    
                <section class="header GHead" id="v927502"><span itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/MedicalCause" ></span><header><h3 id="" ><span itemprop="name"><a id="v927503"></a>Airway obstruction</span></h3></header><div><div><a id="v927504" class="anchor"></a>
<div class="para" >

    <p >Obstruction may involve the</p>
</div>

<div class="list">

    <ul data-mmanualobjecttype="List"  >
            <li><a id="v927508" class="anchor"></a>
<div class="para" >

    <p >Upper airway</p>
</div>
</li>
            <li><a id="v927510" class="anchor"></a>
<div class="para" >

    <p >Lower airway</p>
</div>
</li>
    </ul>
</div>

<a id="v927511" class="anchor"></a>
<div class="para" >

    <p >Infants <span class ="symbol"  ><</span> 3 mo are usually nose breathers and thus may have upper airway obstruction secondary to nasal blockage. At all ages, loss of muscular tone with decreased consciousness may cause upper airway obstruction as the posterior portion of the tongue displaces into the oropharynx. Other causes of upper airway obstruction include blood, mucus, vomitus, or foreign body; spasm or edema of the vocal cords; and pharyngolaryngeal tracheal inflammation (eg, epiglottitis, croup), tumor, or trauma. Patients with congenital developmental disorders often have abnormal upper airways that are more easily obstructed.</p>
</div>

<a id="v927512" class="anchor"></a>
<div class="para" >

    <p >Lower airway obstruction may result from aspiration, bronchospasm, airspace filling disorders (eg, <a href="/professional/pulmonary-disorders/pneumonia/overview-of-pneumonia">pneumonia</a>, <a href="/professional/cardiovascular-disorders/heart-failure/pulmonary-edema">pulmonary edema</a>, pulmonary hemorrhage), or <a href="/professional/injuries-poisoning/drowning/drowning">drowning</a>.</p>
</div>

</div></div></section><section class="header GHead" id="v927513"><span itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/MedicalCause" ></span><header><h3 id="" ><span itemprop="name"><a id="v927514"></a>Decreased respiratory effort</span></h3></header><div><div><a id="v927515" class="anchor"></a>
<div class="para" >

    <p >Decreased respiratory effort reflects CNS impairment due to one of the following:</p>
</div>

<div class="list">

    <ul data-mmanualobjecttype="List"  >
            <li><a id="v927519" class="anchor"></a>
<div class="para" >

    <p >Central nervous system disorder</p>
</div>
</li>
            <li><a id="v927521" class="anchor"></a>
<div class="para" >

    <p >Adverse drug effect</p>
</div>
</li>
            <li><a id="v927523" class="anchor"></a>
<div class="para" >

    <p >Metabolic disorder</p>
</div>
</li>
    </ul>
</div>

<a id="v927524" class="anchor"></a>
<div class="para" >

    <p >CNS disorders that affect the brain stem (eg, stroke, infection, tumor) can cause hypoventilation. Disorders that increase intracranial pressure usually cause hyperventilation initially, but hypoventilation may develop if the brain stem is compressed.</p>
</div>

<a id="v927525" class="anchor"></a>
<div class="para" >

    <p >Drugs that decrease respiratory effort include opioids and sedative-hypnotics (eg, barbiturates, alcohol; less commonly, benzodiazepines). Usually, an overdose (iatrogenic, intentional, or unintentional) is involved, although a lower dose may decrease effort in patients who are more sensitive to the effects of these drugs (eg, the elderly, deconditioned patients, patients with chronic respiratory insufficiency).</p>
</div>

<a id="v927526" class="anchor"></a>
<div class="para" >

    <p >CNS depression due to severe hypoglycemia or hypotension ultimately compromises respiratory effort.</p>
</div>

</div></div></section><section class="header GHead" id="v927527"><span itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/MedicalCause" ></span><header><h3 id="" ><span itemprop="name"><a id="v927528"></a>Respiratory muscle weakness</span></h3></header><div><div><a id="v927530" class="anchor"></a>
<div class="para" >

    <p >Weakness may be caused by</p>
</div>

<div class="list">

    <ul data-mmanualobjecttype="List"  >
            <li><a id="v927533" class="anchor"></a>
<div class="para" >

    <p >Neuromuscular disorders</p>
</div>
</li>
            <li><a id="v927535" class="anchor"></a>
<div class="para" >

    <p >Fatigue</p>
</div>
</li>
    </ul>
</div>

<a id="v927536" class="anchor"></a>
<div class="para" >

    <p >Neuromuscular causes include spinal cord injury, neuromuscular diseases (eg, <a href="/professional/neurologic-disorders/peripheral-nervous-system-and-motor-unit-disorders/myasthenia-gravis">myasthenia gravis</a>,<a href="/professional/infectious-diseases/anaerobic-bacteria/botulism">botulism</a>, <a href="/professional/infectious-diseases/enteroviruses/poliomyelitis">poliomyelitis</a>, <a href="/professional/neurologic-disorders/peripheral-nervous-system-and-motor-unit-disorders/guillain-barré-syndrome-gbs">Guillain-Barré syndrome</a>), and neuromuscular blocking drugs.</p>
</div>

<a id="v927537" class="anchor"></a>
<div class="para" >

    <p >Respiratory muscle fatigue can occur if patients breathe for extended periods at a minute ventilation exceeding about 70% of their maximum voluntary ventilation (eg, because of severe metabolic acidosis or hypoxemia).</p>
</div>

</div></div></section>
    
            </div>
        </section>
        <section id="v927538" class="header  FHead" itemprop="signOrSymptom" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/MedicalSignOrSymptom">
            <header>
                <h2 id="" ><a id="v927539"></a>Symptoms and Signs</h2>
    
            </header>
            <div class="header-body">
                <a id="v927540" class="anchor"></a>
<div class="para" >

    <p >With respiratory arrest, patients are unconscious or about to become so.</p>
</div>

<a id="v927541" class="anchor"></a>
<div class="para" >

    <p >Patients with hypoxemia may be cyanotic, but cyanosis can be masked by anemia or by carbon monoxide or cyanide intoxication. Patients being treated with high-flow oxygen may not be hypoxemic and therefore may not exhibit cyanosis or desaturation until after respiration ceases for several minutes. Conversely, patients with chronic lung disease and polycythemia may exhibit cyanosis without respiratory arrest. If respiratory arrest remains uncorrected, cardiac arrest follows within minutes of onset of hypoxemia, hypercarbia, or both.</p>
</div>


    
                <section class="header GHead" id="v927542"><span itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/MedicalSignOrSymptom" ></span><header><h3 id="" ><span itemprop="name"><a id="v927543"></a>Impending respiratory arrest</span></h3></header><div><div><a id="v927544" class="anchor"></a>
<div class="para" >

    <p >Before complete respiratory arrest, patients with intact neurologic function may be agitated, confused, and struggling to breathe. Tachycardia and diaphoresis are present; there may be intercostal or sternoclavicular retractions. Patients with CNS impairment or respiratory muscle weakness have feeble, gasping, or irregular respirations and paradoxical breathing movements. Patients with a foreign body in the airway may choke and point to their necks, exhibit inspiratory stridor, or neither. Monitoring end-tidal CO<sub>2</sub> can alert practitioners to impending respiratory arrest in decompensating patients.</p>
</div>

<a id="v927545" class="anchor"></a>
<div class="para" >

    <p >Infants, especially if <span class ="symbol"  ><</span> 3 mo, may develop acute apnea without warning, secondary to overwhelming infection, metabolic disorders, or respiratory fatigue. Patients with asthma or with other chronic lung diseases may become hypercarbic and fatigued after prolonged periods of respiratory distress and suddenly become obtunded and apneic with little warning, despite adequate oxygen saturation.</p>
</div>

</div></div></section>
    
            </div>
        </section>
        <section id="v927547" class="header  FHead" >
            <header>
                <h2 id="" ><a id="v927548"></a>Diagnosis</h2>
    
            </header>
            <div class="header-body">
                <div class="list">

    <ul data-mmanualobjecttype="List"  >
            <li><a id="v927552" class="anchor"></a>
<div class="para" >

    <p >Clinical evaluation</p>
</div>
</li>
    </ul>
</div>

<a id="v927553" class="anchor"></a>
<div class="para" >

    <p >Respiratory arrest is usually clinically obvious; treatment begins simultaneously with diagnosis. The first consideration is to exclude a foreign body obstructing the airway; if a foreign body is present, resistance to ventilation is marked during mouth-to-mask or bag-valve-mask ventilation. Foreign material may be discovered during laryngoscopy for endotracheal intubation (see <a href="/professional/critical-care-medicine/respiratory-arrest/airway-establishment-and-control#v927609">Airway Establishment and Control : Clearing and Opening the Upper Airway</a> for removal).</p>
</div>


    
                
    
            </div>
        </section>
        <section id="v927557" class="header  FHead" itemprop="possibleTreatment" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/MedicalTherapy">
            <header>
                <h2 id="" ><a id="v927558"></a>Treatment</h2>
    
            </header>
            <div class="header-body">
                <div class="list">

    <ul data-mmanualobjecttype="List"  >
            <li><a id="v28604811" class="anchor"></a>
<div class="para" >

    <p >Clearing the airway</p>
</div>
</li>
            <li><a id="v28604813" class="anchor"></a>
<div class="para" >

    <p >Mechanical ventilation</p>
</div>
</li>
    </ul>
</div>

<a id="v927559" class="anchor"></a>
<div class="para" >

    <p >Treatment is clearing the airway, <a href="/professional/critical-care-medicine/respiratory-arrest/airway-establishment-and-control">establishing an alternate airway</a>, and providing <a href="/professional/critical-care-medicine/respiratory-failure-and-mechanical-ventilation/overview-of-mechanical-ventilation">mechanical ventilation</a>.</p>
</div>


    
                
    
            </div>
        </section>

</div>
        </section>
